title: 104_hr4008
content:
The Act titled "Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1996" prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1996 prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information, including denial, cancellation, or refusal to renew coverage, varying premiums, or discriminating based on genetic test results. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1996 prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information, including denial, cancellation, or refusal to renew coverage, varying premiums, or discriminating based on genetic test results. Insurers and group health plans are restricted from collecting or disclosing genetic information or requiring genetic tests from individuals seeking health insurance coverage. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1996 prohibits insurers and group health plans from disclosing genetic information without written authorization from the individual, specifying the information, recipient, and purpose. Exceptions include disclosures authorized by criminal laws. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1996 prohibits insurers and group health plans from disclosing genetic information without written authorization, except in specific circumstances such as criminal investigations, court orders, establishing paternity, providing genetic information for medical diagnosis, or identifying a body. Each insurer and group health plan must disclose rights under this section as required by the Secretary. Enforcement of requirements for insurers is done by State insurance commissioners or designated officials. States must ensure insurers meet these requirements for health insurance coverage. The Secretary enforces requirements for insurers who fail to comply with health insurance coverage regulations. If a State does not enforce the plan, the Secretary will implement an enforcement plan, subjecting violators to civil enforcement under specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Secretary of Labor enforces health insurance coverage regulations for group health plans, similar to provisions in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Individuals have the right to bring civil actions for violations and seek various forms of relief, including monetary damages, in state courts. State and federal courts have jurisdiction over actions related to health insurance coverage regulations for group health plans. District courts in the United States can grant relief in any action without regard to the amount in controversy or the parties' citizenship. Venue provisions from title 28 of the United States Code apply. The Secretary and the Secretary of Labor can create necessary regulations to enforce this section. (e) Applicability.-- States can enforce requirements for insurers or health insurance coverage as long as they are not less restrictive than federal requirements. This section does not affect the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Group health plans are not required to provide benefits to specific participants or beneficiaries. 

(f) Definitions.-- "Genetic information" is defined for the purposes of this Act. Genetic information refers to details about genes, gene products, or inherited traits from an individual or their blood-relative. A genetic test determines the presence of genetic characteristics. A group health plan includes any plan providing medical benefits. Health insurance coverage is a contractual arrangement for medical provision. "Coverage refers to a contractual arrangement for health care provision or payment, including hospital or medical expense policies, service plans, and health maintenance organization contracts. An insurer is an entity licensed to provide health insurance coverage, excluding group health plans." Effective Date: This section applies to health insurance coverage and group health plans after 90 days from the enactment of this Act.
